title: Sarba Siksha Abhyan Modular Schools
description: A scalable and site-adaptable modular school prototype developed under the Sarba Siksha Abhyan initiative, aimed at strengthening secondary education infrastructure across Assam. Designed to be deployed across multiple locations, the plan emphasizes repeatability without compromising on contextual relevance or educational quality.

sections.content: This G+2 modular school prototype has been conceived as a scalable and site-adaptable solution under the Sarba Siksha Abhyan initiative, aimed at strengthening secondary education infrastructure across Assam. Designed to be deployed across multiple locations, the plan emphasizes repeatability without compromising on contextual relevance or educational quality.

This G+2 modular school uses three typologies—L-shaped, C-shaped, and Linear—based on a flexible grid for varied site conditions. Type A offers maximum daylight and ventilation, Type B is compact with a courtyard, and Type C suits narrow plots. Classrooms feature cross ventilation, storage, and planters for functional, comfortable learning spaces. The design ensures quick, site-responsive deployment across Assam.

Best suited for narrow or constrained sites, this form has satisfactory daylight and ventilation, with no internal courtyard. The ramp is positioned externally, and a full butterfly roof maximizes water drainage efficiency.

Offers excellent cross ventilation and daylight with a spacious 20×32m courtyard. This layout is ideal for larger sites and provides the most open interaction space. Ramp runs along the interior, and the roof follows a half butterfly form.

A compact version with a 12×12m courtyard and good ventilation and lighting. The layout creates a semi-enclosed central green space, encouraging community interaction. Suitable for medium-sized plots.

The G+2 modular school ensures thermal comfort through cross ventilation, operable louvered windows, and ventilated lofts under sloped roofs. Efficient airflow, daylight optimization, and passive cooling strategies create a sustainable, low-maintenance learning environment suited to Assam’s climate.

client: World Bank, Public Works Department (B) Assam
project_team: Tanisha Sengupta, Mahasweta Bose, Rajnish Rabha, Paran Basumatary
collaborators: Space Ace Architects, Swasti Engineers & Associates

title: Bhupen Hazarika Museum
description: A cultural campus in Assam dedicated to the legendary musician Bhupen Hazarika. The masterplan integrates museums, an auditorium, and open-air gathering spaces through courtyards and shaded walkways, reinterpreting vernacular architecture while anchoring the visitor experience in landscape, light, and memory.

sections.content: VDS is leading the design of a cultural campus in Assam dedicated to the legendary musician Bhupen Hazarika. Located in a lush, tree-lined site, the masterplan weaves together museums, an auditorium, and open-air gathering spaces through a series of courtyards and shaded walkways. The design reinterprets vernacular typologies with rhythmic wooden louvers and deep overhangs, while anchoring the visitor experience in landscape, light, and memory.

The master plan is conceived as an interconnected cultural spine — seamlessly integrating the museum halls, an auditorium, guest lodging, dining, and landscaped zones. Each function is placed to create intuitive movement and layered experiences, encouraging pause, interaction, and exploration.

Set within a tapestry of water bodies and native greens, the architecture is elevated to embrace the land it rests on. Pathways meander through shaded verandahs, open courts, and reflective ponds—blurring the lines between built and unbuilt. The design fosters quiet discovery while framing moments of gathering, memory, and reflection.

Layered around a central courtyard, the buildings are arranged with deliberate porosity—offering moments of pause, shade, and discovery. Deep overhangs and terracotta-hued louvres evoke a vernacular familiarity while tempering the tropical sun. Sculptural landscape elements, including a bust of Bhupen Hazarika, ground the architecture in memory and place.

Elevated volumes with deep overhangs define the architectural language of the campus, creating shaded courtyards and breezeways. These floating masses house key academic and cultural functions, while the verandahs and open corridors below foster social interaction. The design draws from vernacular principles, balancing mass and void to encourage natural light, ventilation, and moments of pause within the institutional rhythm.

At dusk, the campus becomes a quiet stage—where light, sculpture, and landscape perform in harmony. Subtle illumination highlights the rhythmic louvres, while curated sculptures offer a contemplative pause in the institutional rhythm.

client: Public Works Department (B) Assam, Bhupen Hazarika Cultural Trust
project_team: Vikramm B Shroff, Mahasweta Bose, Rajnish Rabha, Paran Basumatary

title: Shanti Villa
description: Shanti Villa is a five-storey luxury residence in the heart of Dimapur, Nagaland, conceived as a vertically stacked, multi-functional home that integrates a full-fledged clinic on the ground floor with a contemporary residence above. The client—a medical professional—envisioned a home that reflects their lifestyle: rooted in care, precision, and calm luxury. In its totality, Shanti Villa represents urban adaptability and understated luxury, turning spatial limitations into a highly personalized living and healing environment.

sections.content: Shanti Villa is a five-storey luxury residence in the heart of Dimapur, Nagaland, conceived as a vertically stacked, multi-functional home that integrates a full-fledged clinic on the ground floor with a contemporary residence above. The client—a medical professional—envisioned a home that reflects their lifestyle: rooted in care, precision, and calm luxury. In its totality, Shanti Villa represents urban adaptability and understated luxury, turning spatial limitations into a highly personalized living and healing environment.

When appointed, the RCC shell was already in place. This posed the key design challenge: how to transform a rigid frame into a layered spatial experience that balances professional needs with intimate family life. This was a story of reinvention—an RCC structure reborn, breathing new life into a dense urban fabric.

A quiet threshold in warm tones and crafted details, this entryway sets the tone for the refined narrative ahead. It opens into a sequence of light-filled living and dining areas—layered with tactile finishes, curated accents, and an effortless elegance that defines the home.

The first floor unfolds as a gracious welcome zone—designed for entertaining and hosting extended family. Anchored by a warm-toned formal lounge, the space features a rich interplay of textures: tan leather seating, a deep green fabric-clad wall, and curated art moments.
The dining area features a bespoke stone-top table with geometric base detailing, surrounded by suede-finished chairs and ambient pendant lights—bringing drama and elegance to everyday dining.

This floor is where the home breathes—an open, lived-in space anchored by the informal living lounge and dining area. The living zone is warm yet restrained, with plush upholstery, sculptural lighting, and tactile finishes that offer comfort without compromise. Arched doorways and layered wall treatments elevate the spatial rhythm.

A quiet choreography of texture and light, the central corridor on the third-floor acts as both threshold and experience. Fluted shutters, cane-faced storage, and a nostalgic Kolkata cityscape painting create a warm, tactile prelude to the private zones beyond.

The master bedroom extends this sensibility with a palette of deep woods, soft taupes, and brushed brass. A curved fluted headboard anchors the space, while layered lighting and muted tones evoke quiet sophistication and restful luxury.

The daughter’s bedroom is expressive yet grounded—an arched coral entry, dusty rose velvets, and brass detailing balance softness with structure. Graphic art and clean-lined furniture add clarity. The son’s room leans into cool minimalism—pale sage walls, monochrome art, and gloss-lacquered storage create a calm, composed retreat. A sculptural brass lamp adds a bold accent. Together, these rooms reflect the home’s ethos of quiet individuality and considered detail.

project_leader: Vikramm B Shroff and Pooza Agarwal
project_team: Prasanta Kalita, Rajnish Rabha, Luku Biswakarma, Shiv Shankar, Kishor, Ali, Pouran, Irshad
